race.name: Essential Gravel
race.tagline: Self-supported gravel through unmarked Wisconsin forest roads near Ringle.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Wisconsin countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Wisconsin event. Rolling terrain with good access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Essential Gravel is a local event in Wisconsin—rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Wisconsin countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Wisconsin gravel race. Worth it for Wisconsin/Midwest riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Wisconsin—yes, it's good value. If you're traveling—skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Wisconsin races: Chequamegon, Bear 100.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Ringle has limited lodging options. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Ringle has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Wisconsin rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Start and finish at Mountain-Bay Trailhead with parking at the Marathon County landfill location. No packet pickup—just show up anytime during the two-week window with a Wisconsin state trail pass (waived first weekend in June). One rider notes it's "easy to follow a nice mix of trails and roads," though the self-supported format means downloading GPS files and cue sheets beforehand.

length.explanation: Three distance options (10, 20, and 44 miles) with course designer Shane Hitz noting the routes are "relatively flat." Todd and Suzanne Meerdink completed the event as "Suzanne's first-ever gravel ride," illustrating how the variable distances accommodate beginners. The flexible window lets riders tackle appropriate distances without the pressure of mass start pacing. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Rail-trail riding on Mountain-Bay and Wiouwash State Trails with "many boardwalks" and railroad trestles. The route is approximately "50% gravel, 50% paved" through eastern Marathon County farm fields and forested gravel roads. Technical challenges stay modest on converted railroad corridors designed for multiple users rather than advanced bike handling. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Shane Hitz describes all three loop options as "relatively flat" in eastern Marathon County. The converted railroad corridors follow gentle grades originally designed for trains, passing "four remote lakes" and "numerous farm fields" rather than sustained climbing. Any elevation challenges come from shorter sections between the lake-dotted terrain. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 78°F and lows of 58°F, with a 52% chance of rain on any given day. Late May through mid-June timing provides a two-plus week window to dodge bad weather entirely. The self-supported format means you control when to ride, avoiding weather-related mechanical challenges during fixed-date events. Smart scheduling for Wisconsin's variable spring conditions with complete flexibility to pick favorable days. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Ringle sits around 1200 feet in central Wisconsin—essentially sea level for cycling purposes. Zero altitude considerations or acclimatization needed, with air density as thick as it gets in the continental US. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The self-supported aspect adds independence on unmarked routes through "forested gravel roads" with opportunities for solitude. One rider enjoyed "beautiful scenery" including historic train depot in Eland and multiple railroad trestles. Adventure quotient stays modest on shared-use corridors never far from Highway 29 and civilization.

prestige.explanation: This is literally a free, self-supported ride where you show up whenever you want during the window. Shane Hitz designed it as "perfect for someone new to gravel riding," with results self-reported to Facebook for prize drawings. It's positioned as an intro event to get people into gravel—which defines its place in the hierarchy.

race_quality.explanation: Zero infrastructure beyond trailhead parking, with self-reported times tracked via Facebook. One rider found it "a great distance" with good route marking via downloadable GPS files. The production value matches the free entry point, with QR codes at the finish directing to result submission forms rather than timing systems.

experience.explanation: Park at a Highway 29 trailhead and ride rail-trail loops solo whenever you feel like it during the window. Andrea Larson emphasizes making it "not just competitive, but fun" with random prize drawings. No packet pickup, post-ride gathering, or community beyond online result sharing and discount codes for other IRONBULL events.

community.explanation: In 2020, two-thirds of riders completed their first-ever gravel ride here, with over half being new to the sport in 2021. Andrea Larson notes they "want to encourage all ability levels" with multiple ways to win prizes beyond being fastest. Part of the IRONBULL 501(c)(3) mission introducing people to outdoor recreation through accessible events.

field_depth.explanation: Free entry with no registration limits during a two-week window attracts beginners by design. The event explicitly welcomes riders "participating in their first-ever gravel ride" like Suzanne Meerdink across three distance options. Depth comes from volume and encouragement rather than competitive talent—exactly 50% experienced state trails for the first time in 2021. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Completely free entry makes this unbeatable on cost, requiring only a Wisconsin state trail pass (waived first weekend in June). Every finisher earns discounts on other IRONBULL events like Red Granite Grinder. Andrea Larson created free events during 2020 pandemic response, then "recognized its value" for ongoing community access to gravel riding.

expenses.explanation: Beyond free entry, typical Wisconsin travel costs to reach Highway 29 trailhead location. The flexible timing eliminates premium lodging needs since you can ride any day during the window. Trail pass runs minimal ($5 annual) unless you hit the waiver weekend, keeping total costs extremely low for accessing quality rail-trail networks. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
